title: Sample Project - Project Charta
text:
Formulate the problem and important information about the domain and/or business area in which the product is to be developed: What exactly is the problem and the expected benefit of the project? Why should we undertake this effort?
This includes a summary of the most important findings from the user analysis: relevant segments and user groups. Describe the problems and needs of the users of the product to be developed.
Stakeholders: List the people involved in and affected by the project. Describe their goals and relationships with each other. Visualisation in the form of a stakeholder map can provide a quick overview.
You can reference more detailed analyses such as individual ‚Äúpersonas‚Äù or interviews in separate documents in the appendix.



Describe the available resources (personnel, material, (software) tools, infrastructure, etc.) and time as well as restrictions and constraints. Possible risks that may arise during the project are also identified.



When is the project successful from a client/stakeholder perspective: Formulate (qualitative) objectives, wherever possible, corresponding key metrics and the target values to be achieved within the project.
It is also often helpful to specify what is explicitly excluded from the project objectives (out of scope).



Map the problem definition, datasets to be used and primary objective onto a data mining task, e.g.:

Classification
Regression
Clustering
Outlier Detection
Association rule learning (market basket analysis)
Recommender System
Visualisation
‚Ä¶

Along with the definition of the actual technical problem (category) to be solved, the project goals must be mapped onto quitable quantitative metrics and corresponding target values. For example, for a classification task one might specify an F-score of 0.9 as a minimal requirement for an acceptable solution.
Such a requirement should be aligned with the overall project goals and/or literature references or justified by other references, respectively.



Divide the project into individual phases, describe them briefly and draw up a preliminary timetable, e.g.¬†as a Gantt chart:
gantt
    title A Gantt Diagram
    dateFormat YYYY-MM-DD
    tickInterval 5day
    section Project Understanding
        Define problem,     :a1, 2024-07-01, 1d
        Determine project goals     :a2, 2024-07-01, 1d
        List available resources     :a3, 2024-07-02, 1d
        Set data mining goals    :a4, 2024-07-03, 1d
        Create project plan    :a5, 2024-07-03, 1d
        Project checkpoint: milestone, m1, 2024-07-04, 4m
    section Data Acquisition and Exploration
        Acquire data :a6, 2024-07-02, 2d
        Exploratory data analysis   :a7, 2024-07-03, 2d
        
    section Modelling
        Create initial model   :a8, 2024-07-09, 1d
        Additional feature engineering :a9, 2024-07-10, 1d
        Prepare modelling report :a10, 2024-07-10, 2h
    section Evaluation
        Prepare presentation :a10, 2024-07-10, 2h
        Project presentation : milestone, m2, 2024-07-11, 4m
See Mermaid syntax for Gantt charts.



List the people involved in the development work here with their role titles, tasks and contact details

title: Sample Project - Modelling Report
text:
The report should summarise the details of the modelling activities, e.g.¬†machine learning experiments.



Aim of the modelling - consistent with Data Mining Goals in the project charta
Data set(s) and/or feature set used (references to the data report)
Description of the independent variables and (if applicable) the target variable
Type of model used or developed




Overview of the models used and/or implemented and their configurations

Detailed description of the model used (e.g.¬†literature references, specification of the software library, exact module, version or other implementation details etc.)
Graphical representation of the modelling pipeline
If applicable: link to the code of the modelling pipeline, version information in code repository, configuration files
If possible, links to the artefacts of the executed modelling pipeline (training experiment)
Link to the literature in which the model/method is described
Hyperparameters




Key figures dependent on the model and modelling objective

RMSD, ROC/Lift-Charts, AUC, Confusion Matrix, Accuracy, Precision, Recall
Coherence, Perplexity, ‚Ä¶
If applicable: analyses/plots of (hyper)parameter screenings





If applicable: Results from the application of ‚Äúexplanatory models‚Äù
Were the modelling objectives achieved?
The findings resulting from the modelling phase: can the project objective be achieved with the results from the modelling phase?
How can the findings be used? Are there any limitations?





Conclusions of the key findings from the modelling phase
Discussion about limitations
Proposal for extensions and further work
Proposal for the deployment of the generated insights/model

title: About This Documentation
text:
The Data Science Process [1]






References

1. Doemer D, Kempf M. Is it ops that make data science scientific? Archives of Data Science, Series A (Online First). 2022;8(2):12 S.

title: Evaluation Protocol
text:
This protocol documents the decisions taken at the evaluation stage of the Real Estate Price Predictor project. The evaluation was conducted in a team workshop on 2025-07-24, with the aim of assessing whether the results of the data mining phase meet user needs and whether to proceed to deployment.





Name
Role




Josh Richter
Data Engineer


Alessandro Mazzeo
ML Developer


Antonie Michael Verdile
Full Stack Developer


Enmanuel Lizardo
Data Scientist








Yes.
The developed Random Forest models achieved high predictive performance, surpassing the minimum success criteria outlined in the Project Charta (R¬≤ > 0.75, MAE < 300 CHF). The models provide accurate, interpretable predictions for both rental and purchase markets and are ready for integration into a dashboard for user interaction.



Yes.
The team unanimously decided to proceed with deployment and further development. The results were deemed robust and aligned with the project goals.



Deployment will include: - Integrating the trained Random Forest models into a web-based user interface. - Backend implementation of the prediction API. - Monitoring and maintenance plan for the deployed models. - Documentation of model assumptions and limitations for transparency.
Planned timeline: see Project Gantt Chart ‚Äî Phase 4: Visualization (2025-07-24 through 2025-07-28).



Not required at this stage. However, the following future enhancements were noted: - Augment data with external sources such as demographic and transport data. - Improve clustering methods by incorporating domain-specific ontologies. - Reassess governance and ethics as data privacy regulations evolve.





Presentation slides (PDF)




The final product to be deployed is a web-based prediction dashboard that: - Allows users to input property features and obtain real-time price predictions. - Visualizes prediction confidence and key feature contributions. - Offers insights into market segmentation (via clusters) and trends.



The team acknowledges the limitations identified in the modelling phase, particularly: - Market dynamics not yet accounted for. - Dependence on scraped data quality and completeness.
These points will be addressed in future project iterations.

title: Data Report
text:
All information on the data used in the project is compiled in this data report to ensure the traceability and reproducibility of the results and to enable a systematic expansion of the database.
Typically, in the exploratory analysis of the acquired raw data, quality and other issues are identified, which require pre-processing, merging of individual datasets and feature engineering into processed datasets. Therefore, this report provides a separate section for the processed data, which then serves as a starting point for the modelling activities.

title: Data Report
text:
Raw Data

Overview Raw Datasets



Name
Source
Storage Location




Flatfox Listings
flatfox.ch (rental offers)
output_flatfox.json


UrbanHome Rentals
urbanhome.ch (rental offers)
output_urbanhome.json


UrbanHome Sales
urbanhome.ch (buy offers)
output_urbanhome_buy.json





Details Dataset 1: Flatfox Listings

Description: Contains real estate rental listings scraped from flatfox.ch, including title, address, ZIP code, city, price, rooms, area in sqm, availability, etc.
Source/Provider: Flatfox.ch
Procurement: Collected using custom Python scraper using Selenium and BeautifulSoup
Reproducibility: Team members can rerun scraping using the script in the GitHub repository under Flatfox Scraper
Legal: Only publicly accessible data is used; terms of use must be checked regularly.
Governance: Business-relevant, anonymized
Variable roles:

Dependent: price
Independent: rooms, area_sqm, floor, zip_code, has_balcony, city




Details Dataset 2: UrbanHome Rentals

Description: Rental property listings collected from urbanhome.ch, with attributes such as location, price, size, and availability.
Source/Provider: UrbanHome.ch
Procurement: Scraped using a Selenium-based Python script; similar structure to Flatfox data
Reproducibility: Fully reproducible via the Urbanhome Scraper script in the repository
Legal: Publicly available data; periodically verify platform terms of use
Governance: Public and business-relevant
Variable roles:

Dependent: price
Independent: rooms, area_sqm, floor, zip_code, has_balcony, city




Details Dataset 3: UrbanHome Sales

Description: Contains residential real estate listings offered for sale on urbanhome.ch, with structured fields similar to rental data.
Source/Provider: UrbanHome.ch
Procurement: Collected via a custom web scraping script urbanhome_buy_scraper.py
Reproducibility: Executable with documented script under the Urbanhome Scraper
Legal: Scraped from publicly accessible offers; non-personal data
Governance: Public, business-relevant
Variable roles:

Dependent: price
Independent: rooms, area_sqm, zip_code, city, has_balcony, floor

title: Data Report
text:
Data Quality
During initial exploratory analysis, the following issues were identified:

Some listings contain missing price, area_sqm, or rooms values.
Inconsistencies in zip_code formats (some as strings, some as ints)
Mixed granularity in rooms values (e.g.¬†1 vs 1.0 vs 1.5 vs 3 ¬Ω)
Incomplete or overly long free-text description fields
Duplicate or nearly duplicate entries (due to reposts or scrape overlaps)

These issues required cleaning steps such as deduplication, type normalization, filtering and imputation.

title: Data Report
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
To better understand the data structure and identify patterns, we conducted an exploratory analysis on the cleaned listings.

Details Processed Dataset 1: Cleaned Listings

Description: Cleaned and unified dataset combining all rental listings with harmonized schema. Unused fields removed, null values handled.
Processing steps:

Merging listings from Flatfox and UrbanHome
Filtering to retain only listings with all essential fields (price, rooms, area_sqm, zip_code)
Normalizing values (e.g., numeric parsing, boolean flags)
Feature engineering (e.g., price_per_sqm, encoded ZIP region)

Access: Available in cleaned_data.json. Generated using data_preparation.py script in project repo.

title: Data Report
text:
(Optional) Entity Relationship Diagram
Not applicable ‚Äì data is stored as flat JSON records.

title: Project Charta
text:
What is the problem?
The challenge is to develop a machine learning system that predicts the rental or selling price of residential properties. Currently, renters and buyers rely on manual and often subjective methods to assess property value. This leads to inefficiencies, missed opportunities, and mispriced listings.
Domain/Business Area
The project operates within the Swiss real estate market, involving rental agencies, private buyers and sellers, and expanding corporations. Real estate platforms like UrbanHome, ImmoScout24 and others are relevant sources.
Expected Benefit
The tool will help users, especially renters and buyers, find properties with the best price-to-quality ratio. It provides landlords and sellers with better pricing strategies and enables data-driven decision-making.
Why this effort?
An ML-powered property price predictor can dramatically reduce the time and uncertainty involved in the property search process. By learning from real data, the model helps stakeholders make informed choices aligned with their financial and lifestyle needs.
Stakeholders









Stakeholder
Role
Goal
Relationship




Buyers/Renters
Users of the predictor
Find the best value-for-money home
Interested in accuracy and usability


Sellers/Landlords
Input providers and users
Price fairly and competitively
Interested in fair predictions


Project Team
Developers and analysts
Build the system within 4 weeks
Provides value to both user groups


Data Sources
Real estate websites (UrbanHome etc.)
Provide structured/unstructured data
Data dependency






Resources
- Personnel: 3 people
- Software/Tools: VS Code, Python, SQLite, HTML, JS, CSS
- Infrastructure: Local development environments
- Data Sources: Real estate listing websites
- Time: 4 weeks (192 hours total)
Constraints
- All data must be acquired from public websites via scraping.
- Must handle dynamic content, inconsistent formats, and ensure data privacy and legality.
Restrictions
- Limited project time and small team size.
- No access to private or premium datasets.
Risks
- Lack of deep experience in ML model optimization.
- Time constraints may limit dashboard and DL integration quality.



Qualitative Goals
- Develop a working ML model that predicts property prices.
- Visualize the results in a user-friendly dashboard.
- Enhance accuracy with tabular and image-based features.
Success Criteria and Metrics
- At least 1,000 unique properties scraped and processed.
- Classical regression model achieves MAE < 300 CHF or R¬≤ > 0.75.
- Dashboard allows users to query a property and receive a predicted price.
- Integration of deep learning features shows performance improvement over baseline.
Out of Scope
- Commercial deployment
- Legal contracts, compliance, and regulatory integration
- Mobile applications



Task Mapping
- Primary Task: Regression, to predict continuous property prices.
- Subtasks: - Classification, for image room types or amenity presence - Visualization, for dashboard output and EDA
Datasets to Be Used
- Scraped tabular data (price, rooms, size, location, etc.)
- Downloaded property images
- Optionally enriched with geographic/statistical data from APIs
Target Metrics
- Regression:
- MAE < 300 CHF
- R¬≤ > 0.75
- Classification (images):
- Accuracy > 0.8
- F1-score > 0.75 (for multi-label classification)












Name
Role
Tasks
Contact




Josh Richter
Data Engineer
Web scraping, data cleaning, DB design
richtjos@mail.gvsu.edu


Alessandro Mazzeo
ML Developer
Feature engineering, model training, evaluation
mazzale@students.zhaw.ch


Antonio Michael Verdile
Full Stack Dev
Dashboard development, ML integration, UI/UX design
verdiant@students.zhaw.ch


Enmanuel Lizardo
Data Scientist
Analytics, research, data visualisation
lizardoe@mail.gvsu.edu

title: Modelling Report
text:
The goal of this modelling phase was to build predictive models for real estate pricing, both for rental and purchase markets. This objective aligns with the Data Mining Goals defined in the project charta:
- Predict the price of a property based on structured features
- Evaluate multiple models to select the best-performing one
- Interpret model outputs and determine feasibility for deployment



We used the cleaned and preprocessed dataset described in the Data Report. The dataset includes features such as: - Property characteristics (e.g.¬†size, number of rooms, floor) - Location information (ZIP code, city, longitude/latitude clusters) - Categorical indicators extracted from property descriptions (e.g.¬†keywords)
Target variables: - price_rent (rental market) - price_purchase (purchase market)
References: - See Data Report for preprocessing and feature engineering details.



Three models were tested and compared: - Linear Regression (Baseline) - Random Forest Regressor - XGBoost Regressor
All models were implemented using scikit-learn and xgboost in Python 3.11.
The final selected model was Random Forest, based on its superior performance across evaluation metrics and residual analysis.

- Interpret model outputs and determine feasibility for deployment

The final selected model was Random Forest, based on its superior performance across evaluation metrics and residual analysis.

title: Modelling Report
text:
Software & Libraries

Python 3.11
scikit-learn==1.4.2
xgboost==2.0.3
pandas, numpy, matplotlib, seaborn
Code repository: GitHub Repo Link


Modelling Pipeline





graph TD
    A[Load Data] --> B[Feature Engineering]
    B --> C[Split Data]
    C --> D1[Train LinearRegression]
    C --> D2[Train RandomForest]
    C --> D3[Train XGBoost]
    D1 --> E1[Evaluate Model]
    D2 --> E2[Evaluate Model]
    D3 --> E3[Evaluate Model]








Model Artefacts

RandomForest Model: random_forest_rent.pkl, random_forest_purchase.pkl
Configuration files: config.yml, params.json

title: Modelling Report
text:
Semantic Text Clustering
To enhance the predictive power of property descriptions, we introduced semantic clustering using the SentenceTransformer model all-MiniLM-L6-v2.





graph TD
    A[Load Descriptions] --> B[SentenceTransformer Embedding]
    B --> C[Run KMeans Clustering]
    C --> D[Evaluate with Silhouette Score]
    D --> E[Select Optimal Cluster Number]

title: Modelling Report
text:
Cluster Top Terms
Clusters were labeled using top TF-IDF terms per cluster, translated for stakeholder readability.
Example:

title: Modelling Report
text:
Image Features
Images were embedded using ResNet50, reduced using PCA (100 components), and merged by ID into the model.





graph TD
    A[Download Images] --> B[ResNet50 Feature Extraction]
    B --> C[PCA Reduction]
    C --> D[Join with Main DataFrame]

title: Modelling Report
text:
Feature Engineering Summary



Feature Source
Example Features




Structured
area, log_area_sqm, is_top_floor


Semantic Clusters
description_cluster


Image PCA
img_pca_0 ‚Ä¶ img_pca_99


Geo Binning
lat_bin, lon_bin


Augmented
rare class noise injection

title: Modelling Report
text:
Were the Objectives Achieved?
Yes. The enhanced Random Forest models surpassed baselines and proved suitable for deployment.

title: Modelling Report
text:
Key Findings

Tree-based models outperformed linear models significantly

Combined features led to robust predictions

Clustering added interpretability and segmentation

title: Modelling Report
text:
Limitations

Market dynamics not included in data

Clustering depends on text quality

Image availability varies across properties

title: Modelling Report
text:
Summary

Best performance achieved with Random Forests using enriched feature sets

Pipeline supports automated, reproducible model training

Stakeholder interpretability was prioritized

title: Modelling Report
text:
Future Work

Use external data (transport, demographics)

Explore deep learning and model ensembles

Deploy via REST API and monitor performance

title: Sample Project - Decision Log
text:
Sample Project - Decision Log
This protocol summarises the decisions from the evaluation of the data mining phase, which are made, for example, in a workshop together with the client and other stakeholders.
Decide:

Do results meet user needs?
Continuation of the project yes/no
Planning of the deployment
Carry out an additional data mining iteration

Acquire more or different data
Improvements in the modelling
Address governance issues
or ethical considerations
‚Ä¶


Any presentation material created for such a workshop should also be stored in the docs folder.
It is important to list who was involved in the decisions and when they were made.
The structure and level of detail of this protocol should be tailored to the customs of the relevant organisation and the requirements of the decision-makers. It might include already a high level description of the envisioned product to be deployed.

title: Sample Project - Data Report
text:
All information on the data used in the project is compiled in the data report in order to ensure the traceability and reproducibility of the results and to enable a systematic expansion of the database.
Typically, in the exploratory analysis of the acquired raw data, quality and other issues are identified, which require pre-processing, merging of individual datasets and feature engineering into processed datasets. Therefore, this template provides a separate section for the processed data, which then serves as a starting point for the modelling activities. This needs to be adapted to the specific project requirements.

Information on data procurement: description and possibly references to resources (download scripts, tools, online services, ‚Ä¶). Any new team member should be able to acquire the data indepentendently following these instructions.
Legal aspects of data use, licences, etc.
Data governance aspects: Categorisation of the data based on internal business requirements, e.g.¬†public, business-relevant, personal
If applicable: categorisation into dependent (target variable, regressor) and independent (regressor) variables

The data catalogue basically represents an extended schema of a relational database.
